title: Political instability hinders development. Chairperson Oli highlights the negative impact it has on Nepal's progress.
content: Political instability has slowed development in Nepal. Infrastructure development is key to creating jobs and businesses. The government is committed to improving infrastructure, including roads, railways, and electricity. The government also plans to support small businesses based on agriculture. All political parties should work together to prioritize development.
summary: CPN (UML) acknowledged the impact of political instability on development while emphasizing the importance of infrastructures, SMEs, and cooperation in promoting progress at a seminar on physical infrastructures and transportation.

title: Deputy Prime Minister Lamichhane wants an opportunity to speak in parliament.
content: Deputy Prime Minister Rabi Lamichhane claims he is being denied his right to speak in parliament. He says he should be allowed to defend himself against accusations before a probe committee is formed. He challenges his opponents to prove their claims and accuses the Nepali Congress of trying to control parliament. Lamichhane also reports efforts to apprehend the main suspect in a cooperatives scam.
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lamichhane alleges violation of his parliamentary speech right amid calls for a probe into cooperative issues and challenges accusations against him.

content:
Some parts of Nepal are experiencing light to moderate rain with thunderstorms due to a low-pressure system.

Also expected:
- Light snowfall in high mountains
- Gusty winds
- Rain in most areas, mainly in the evening

Be cautious of impacts on daily life, such as travel and health.
summary: Rain with thunder, lightning and possible snowfall are occurring and forecasted in various provinces of Nepal due to a low-pressure system.

title: Gold price increased by Rs. 2,300 per tola.
content:
Gold price increased by Rs 2,300 per tola in Nepal.

* Hallmark gold: Rs 137,900 per tola
* Worked gold: Rs 137,250 per tola

Silver price increased by Rs 50 per tola to Rs 1,735 per tola.
summary: Gold prices surge in Nepal, with hallmark gold reaching Rs 137,900 per tola, worked gold at Rs 137,250, and silver rising to Rs 1,735 per tola.

title: Wildlife conservation is facing challenges. In the last 10 months, 21 rhinos have been killed.
content:
21 rhinos died in Chitwan National Park in the last 10 months.

2 were killed by poachers, 19 died naturally due to accidents, fighting, old age, or tiger attacks.

More rhinos are dying due to natural causes as their population increases.

The park is managing grasslands and wetlands to save rhinos.

Some rhinos have been moved to the east to give more space.

Currently, there are 694 rhinos in the park.
summary: 21 rhinos died in Chitwan National Park, two due to poaching and 19 due to natural causes such as swamps, fighting, and electrocution, with the population now at 694.

title: European Union pledges to assist Nepal in attracting investment to boost economic growth.
content:
**EU to Help Nepal Attract Investments**

The European Union (EU) will host a meeting in Kathmandu to bring European businesses to Nepal and support its economic growth. The goal is to increase foreign investment and create jobs, as Nepal aims to improve its status as a developing country.
summary: EU pledges assistance to Nepal in attracting European investment through a trade forum aimed at reducing foreign investment deficit.

title: Swiss government to give 9.01 million Swiss francs for tourism project
content:
Switzerland will give Nepal 9 million Swiss francs for a trekking tourism project.
The project will last four years and benefit 100,000 locals in 29 local areas of Koshi Province.
It will support local art, culture, production, job creation and sustainable tourism.
Switzerland believes the project will boost the local economy and promote eco-tourism, leading to more income for locals.
summary: Switzerland grants 9.01 million Swiss francs to Nepal for a four-year trekking tourism project in Koshi Province, benefiting 100,000 locals and promoting sustainable tourism and local development.

title: Person arrested with undisclosed amount of money.
content: Police in Kathmandu arrested two men from Rupandehi: Samir Sunar, 28, and Milan, 29, with an undisclosed amount of Rs 9.8 lakh ($7,000 USD).
summary: Valley Crime Investigation Office arrested Samir Sunar and Milan with Rs 9.8 lakh in Kathmandu.

title: Four students arrested for leaking Grade 12 question papers.
content: Four people were arrested in Kathmandu with leaked answer sheets for the Grade-12 computer science exam. They were caught writing in the answer sheets at a party hall. The police are investigating the incident according to the Education Act.
summary: Kathmandu police arrested four individuals with leaked answer sheets for a Grade-12 computer science exam, leading to an ongoing investigation under the Education Act.

title: Arrest warrants issued for 20 individuals, including former Bal Mandir officials.
content: Arrest warrants have been issued for 20 people, including former officials of the Bal Mandir, a charity for children. They are accused of selling and leasing the charity's land for business purposes, costing the charity money.
summary: Arrest warrants issued against 20 individuals, including former Bal Mandir officials, for embezzlement of charity's land.

title: The President attended a celebration of Law Day, an annual event that promotes understanding of the law and its role in society.
content:
**Law Day Nepal**

On Law Day, Nepal celebrated the anniversary of their Chief Court Act. The Supreme Court organized an event with dignitaries, including the President.

Chief Justice Shrestha emphasized the importance of a fair society with strong constitutional rule and respect for rights. He highlighted the need for cooperation between the judiciary, legal professionals, and the government to deliver justice effectively.

The Law Day event was attended by government officials, judges, lawyers, and media personnel.
summary: Nepal observed Law Day 2081 BS with events showcasing institutional reforms for rule of law, independence of the judiciary, and separation of powers.

title: Businesses call on Prime Minister to approve regular flights at Goa airport.
content: Business leaders in Bhairahawa have asked Prime Minister Dahal to help start regular flights at the Gautam Buddha International Airport. They say the airport needs regular flights to help the local economy. Prime Minister Dahal said he supports their request and is working on it.
summary: Bhairahawa's private sector seeks PM Dahal's support for regular flights at Gautam Buddha International Airport, and he pledges to address the issue.

title: Everest expedition team successfully anchored the ropes to the summit of Mount Everest.
content: Everest climbing season is now open for 2024. A team from Seven Summit Treks fixed ropes to the summit yesterday. Over 950 climbers have already received permission to climb the mountain, including 200 women. The government has collected 67 crores in fees from the climbers.
summary: In preparation for the 2024 spring Everest season, Seven Summit Treks Company completed rope fixing up to the peak, with 956 climbers (including 200 women) receiving permission, resulting in government revenue of over 67 crore rupees.

title: Joshi Dhakal has been promoted to Assistant Inspector General of Nepal Police.
content:
Government promotes Umesh Raj Joshi and Bhim Prasad Dhakal as Additional Inspectors General of Nepal Police.

Also, 42 sports achievers will be awarded for winning medals in taekwondo, kabaddi, karate, and cricket.

Nanda Lal Majhi and Suresh Manandhar have been appointed as Vice Chairman of Social Welfare Council and Member of Language Commission, respectively.
summary: Nepal Police promotes Deputy Inspectors General Joshi & Dhakal, awards 42 sportspersons, and appoints Majhi & Manandhar to key positions.

title: Bridge construction on the Narayangadh-Muglin road is underway, aiming to improve transportation in the region.
content:
Construction on bridges along the Narayangadh-Muglin road is underway.

Out of 19 bridges, 11 are open and 4 are being built.

Two bridges will open by mid-July, while the Tuin Khola bridge will open by mid-November.

Bridge construction was delayed due to cutting a wall near the Tuin stream and compensation issues in Khahare.

New bridges and road improvements have reduced landslides during the rainy season.
summary: Construction of 15 bridges along the Narayangadh-Muglin road is progressing, with 11 already operational and four nearing completion, aiming for full operation by mid-November.

title: 27 people have died due to forest fires and lightning in just 24 days.
content: Over the past 24 days, at least 27 people have died in fires, forest fires, and lightning strikes. 18 people died in fires, 6 in forest fires, and 3 from lightning strikes. 90 people were injured. The government will provide financial assistance to the victims' families to build temporary housing.
summary: In the past 24 days, 27 fatalities have occurred from fire (18), forest fire (6), and lightning (3), injuring 90, while financial assistance has been approved for fire victim families to construct temporary housing.

title: National Assembly meeting postponed due to protest by NC.
content: The National Assembly meeting was postponed because the NC lawmakers protested. They want a parliamentary probe committee to investigate embezzlement in cooperatives before the Assembly can operate. The meeting was delayed for 15 minutes before the NC lawmakers left their seats in protest. The Chairman allowed one NC lawmaker to speak, but the obstruction continued, and the meeting was postponed until May 14th.
summary: Second National Assembly meeting postponed due to NC lawmakers' protest over cooperative embezzlement investigation demand.

title: Parliamentary meeting ended early after opposition members protested.
content: The opposition stopped the House of Representatives meeting again because they wanted a committee to investigate a missing fund. The Speaker tried to let the Deputy Prime Minister speak but was stopped. The meeting was adjourned and will be held again on May 14th.
summary: Nepali Congress obstructs House of Representatives meetings, demanding a probe into cooperative fund embezzlement, leading to adjournment without achieving any progress.

title: Federal Parliament's budget session starts today.
content: The Parliament of Nepal is having a meeting today to discuss the budget for the next year. This meeting was called by President Ramchandra Paudel and all members of Parliament have been asked to attend. The budget will be presented on May 28th. Before that, the President will give a speech about the government's plans for the year. The Speaker of the Parliament has met with leaders from different political parties to make sure the meeting runs smoothly.
summary: Nepal's budget session, mandated by the constitution, commences in a joint parliament session convened by President Paudel, with discussions held to ensure smooth proceedings.

title: Government overlooks concerns raised by the opposition party's Chief Whip, Lekhak.
content:
Nepali Congress official Ramesh Lekhak says the government is ignoring concerns about corruption in cooperatives.

The party wants an investigation and action taken against those responsible for stealing money from thousands of ordinary people.

They also want the cooperative sector, which is important for the economy, to be cleaned up.

The party is not interested in forming a new government with the UML but wants to work with other parties to address people's needs.

Lekhak says it is important for parliament to be effective and responsive to the people's concerns.
summary: The Nepali Congress demands the government investigate embezzlement in cooperatives while denying interest in forming a new government with CPN UML, despite their support for parliamentary consensus.

title: Nepal's Supreme Court to consider legal action against the state over land acquisition in the Bara district.
content: Janata Samajwadi Party (JSP) Nepal will take legal action over a recent party split. A faction led by Ashok Rai has gained recognition as a new party from Nepal's Election Commission. JSP Nepal, led by Upendra Yadav, will hold a meeting to discuss the split and decide on legal options.
summary: Janata Samajwadi Party Nepal led by Upendra Yadav to take legal action against split faction led by Ashok Rai, recognized as a separate party by Election Commission.

title: Minister Joshi demands quick aid to build homes for survivors of the Jajarkot earthquake.
content: Minister Joshi calls for prompt compensation for earthquake victims to build shelters before the rainy season. He highlights the ongoing challenges of natural disasters in Nepal and the need for effective disaster management. He acknowledges the role of the National Reconstruction Authority and the need for stronger partnerships between federal, provincial, and local governments to address the issue of insufficient housing in Karnali Province.
summary: Minister Bhanubhakta Joshi emphasizes the urgent need for prompt compensation and shelter for victims of the Jajarkot earthquake, highlighting ongoing disaster challenges, financial limitations, and the need for effective risk management policies.

title: Tragically, a mother and her son died from burns in a house fire.
content: A 55-year-old mother and her 15-year-old son died in a fire while trying to stop it from spreading. The fire started in a forest near their home and the mother caught fire first while protecting hay. Her son tried to save her but also died. Police are investigating the incident and there have been other forest fires in the area recently.
summary: A mother and son were tragically charred to death in a forest fire in Okhaldhunga while attempting to extinguish it.

title: Two people died and two were injured in a road accident.
content: Two people died in a tractor accident in Dadeldhura. The victims were the driver, Dhiraj Thapamgar, and a passenger, Bishnu BK. Two other passengers were injured and are being treated at the Dadeldhura hospital.
summary: Two individuals perished in a tractor accident in Dadeldhura, with two more sustaining injuries.

title: 24 artifacts returned to Nepal from Hawaii.
content:
The Embassy of Nepal in the US received 24 artifacts from Ms Susan Bradford, who had them in her private collection.

These artifacts, from the 13th to 18th centuries, were sent back to Nepal with Ms Bradford's sponsorship.

The Embassy thanks Ms Bradford for returning these valuable pieces to Nepal.

The Embassy has worked with the US and Nepal to return lost artifacts, and this is the second batch of artifacts they have returned within a year.
summary: 24 Nepali artifacts from the 13th-18th centuries, repatriated from Hawaii to Nepal thanks to Ms. Susan Bradford, add to the Embassy's successful recovery efforts with 63 pieces returned in a year.

title: Kanti Highway is closed due to heavy snowfall and landslides.
content:
Landslide closes Kanti Highway near Lalitpur.

Road collapsed during maintenance work, causing damage to gabion wall.

Vehicle movement stopped until further notice.
summary: A landslide along the Kanti Highway in Lalitpur district has closed the road until further notice due to damage to the gabion wall, disrupting vehicular movement.

title:

* **Condemns violence and loss of life in recent conflict.**
* **Calls for immediate ceasefire and dialogue to avoid escalation.**
* **Urges peaceful resolution through international cooperation and diplomacy.**
* **Stresses the importance of respecting international law and human rights.**

Two countries, Iran and Israel, are fighting, causing international concern.

Their attacks on each other have killed many people, including civilians.

Countries worldwide, including HWPL, are urging Iran and Israel to stop fighting and talk about peace.

HWPL suggests international action to build friendly relations between the countries and provide aid.

Everyone should support peace and laws to prevent war in the future.

Moreover, on 13 April, Iran responded by attacking Israel‚Äôs land. HWPL will not spare its efforts for peace and cessation of wars.

title: Nepal and Korea are preparing for a high-level visit to strengthen ties and cooperation between their countries.
content:
Nepal and South Korea will celebrate 50 years of diplomatic relations.

**High-level officials will visit Nepal for the anniversary.**

The two countries have been close partners, especially in investment and employment:

* South Korea is the 4th largest investor in Nepal.
* Hyundai's assembly plant will open in Nepal soon.
* Over 44,000 Nepalis currently work in South Korea, mostly in agriculture and production.
* Nepalis will now also work in service and forestry sectors in Korea.
* Nepalis who return from South Korea often start businesses, creating jobs in Nepal.
summary: Nepal and South Korea prepare for high-level exchange, mark 50th diplomatic anniversary with events, increased investment, and expanded job opportunities for Nepalis in Korea.

title: Japan and Nepal have similarities and a strong relationship, as stated by Japan's Foreign Minister Kamikawa Yoko.
content:
**Similarities between Japan and Nepal:**

* Mountainous terrain
* Democratic governments

**Assistance from Japan to Nepal:**

* Support for democratization
* Support for legal system development
* Aid after earthquakes (e.g., blankets, rescue teams, funding for reconstruction)
* Infrastructure construction (e.g., roads, tunnels)
* Support for agriculture, education, healthcare

**Growing ties between Japan and Nepal:**

* Direct flights between the two countries
* Over 170,000 Nepalis living in Japan
* Cooperation in "Women, Peace and Security"

**Japan's commitment to supporting Nepal's development**

* Assistance in a wide range of fields
* Focus on building resilience and stability
* Support for Nepal's graduation from Least Developed Country category
summary: Japan and Nepal, both mountainous countries with democratic histories, have faced earthquakes and supported each other, with Japan providing assistance in infrastructure, development, and "Women, Peace and Security."

title: not-to-go-to-foreign-employment-through-illegal-route-embassy
content: Nepali Embassy in Pakistan warns against illegal foreign job offers. Some Nepali have been stranded in Kyrgyzstan after being promised attractive jobs. The embassy urges people to use only legal means for foreign employment to avoid being scammed.
summary:
The Embassy of Nepal in Islamabad has urged all the concerned to only use legal means to go for foreign employment, noting many Nepali have been victimized and stranded in Kyrgyzstan for some time on temptation of attractive jobs.The embassy said it has received information that some of those victimized have been assured to be sent to other countries using Kyrgyzstan route, sharing that some of the stranded people have been rescued and sent back to Nepal, some are on their way back but the process of reaching there has not stopped.
In a statement issued on Tuesday, the embassy said, "As per the information received, some Nepali and foreigners are being involved in the fraudulent acts in the face of lucrative jobs".
Individuals and groups involved in illegal activities of taking Nepali citizens abroad on the wrong temptation and leaving them stranded have to face the prevailing law, the statement further noted.
"The embassy sincerely requests all concerned not to fall prey to the ill-intended act of fraudulent groups and to use only the established and legal route arranged by the Government of Nepal to go for foreign employment", the statement reads.

title: Prime Minister Dahal emphasizes the government's commitment to supporting and protecting investments.
content: Prime Minister Prachanda wants to boost Nepal's economy by encouraging private sector investment. He believes that by supporting businesses, creating a friendly investment climate, and replacing imports with domestic production, Nepal can increase productivity, create jobs, and strengthen the economy. The government has passed laws to encourage investment and hosted an investment summit to attract investors. Prachanda is optimistic that Nepal will become an attractive destination for investment.
summary: PM Dahal inaugurated the Hyundai Motor Assembling Plant in Nawalparasi, emphasizing the government's commitment to economic transformation through investor support and private sector collaboration, aiming to strengthen the economy and create employment opportunities.

title: Transparency and good governance go hand in hand. Transparency helps ensure that government actions and decisions are open and accessible to the public, while good governance promotes accountability, fairness, and participation in public affairs. Together, these principles foster trust and legitimacy in government, leading to better outcomes for citizens.
content:
**Transparency and Good Governance**

President Paudel emphasized that:

* Transparency and good governance go hand-in-hand.
* Auditors are the nation's "economic watchdog," ensuring financial accountability.
* Skilled auditors promote transparency and prevent fraud and tax evasion.
* Nepal needs a credible accounting system for foreign aid and economic development.
summary: President Paudel emphasizes transparency and good governance, highlighting the critical role of auditors (economic watchdogs) in maintaining transparency in economic activities.

title: Prime Minister Dahal will introduce an upcoming budget in a new format, making it easier to understand and implement.
content: PM Prachanda plans to introduce a new approach to the budget and policies for the coming year, focusing on boosting the economy and helping those in need. He emphasized the government's efforts in promoting good governance and social justice, citing achievements in addressing issues such as loan shark victims and land scams. Despite facing criticism, the government remains committed to these initiatives. Additionally, Nepal's international relations have been strengthened through high-level visits.
summary: PM Dahal announces new policies and budget to improve economy, promote socialism, and enhance governance and international relations.

title:
**Nepal Swadeshi Summit 2024**

A 35-point declaration was issued at the Nepal Swadeshi Summit 2024, emphasizing:

* Promoting domestic production and self-reliance.
* Developing infrastructure and creating employment opportunities.
* Encouraging foreign direct investment (FDI) in specific sectors.
* Preserving Nepal's traditional values and culture.
* Ensuring the country's economic independence and national identity.
content:
The Make in Nepal summit ended with a 35-point plan to support local industries and increase domestic production. Key points include:

- Reforming laws to create a favorable environment for businesses.
- Ensuring a smooth supply of raw materials and differentiating customs rates between finished goods and raw materials.
- Establishing a specialized financial institution for industrial investment.
- Prioritizing domestic products for government purchases and creating a portal to identify domestic products.
- Implementing one-stop service centers and developing industrial areas.
- Encouraging domestic production in areas where Nepal has self-sufficiency.
- Imposing fines instead of criminal charges against accused industrialists.
- Regulating the industrial sector through a separate act.
- Reviewing trade and investment agreements.
- Building a consensus among political parties on economic development.
summary: The Make in Nepal Summit concluded with a 35-point declaration focusing on empowering domestic industries, increasing production, and encouraging consumption, including reforms, incentives, and initiatives for investment and industrial development.

title: Economic prosperity for Nepal starts from Dailekh district.
content: Dailekh district could become economically prosperous if the final petroleum drilling in Jaljale is successful. The exploration is expected to conclude in six months and could make Dailekh a major economic hub if substantial petroleum and gas reserves are found. The project has been funded by a Chinese government grant and aims to determine the availability and usability of these natural resources.
summary: Dailekh district hopes for economic prosperity as Minister Bhandari inaugurates final petroleum exploration drilling.

title: Nepalese runners won two titles in Malaysia.
content:
Nepali runner Mahadev Rijal won two consecutive races in Malaysia:

* **Today:** 21 km half marathon in 0:1:14:48 seconds.
* **Yesterday:** 21 km Climbathon event in 3:03:58 seconds.

Rijal also won the 8th Tower Runner competition in Malaysia last year, finishing 8th out of 284 participants. The race course had 83 flights of stairs and an elevation gain of 249 meters.

Rijal is from Beni, Nepal, and has been working in Malaysia for 5 years. He started running in Nepal and continued training in Malaysia.
summary: Nepali runner Mahadev Rijal won the 21 km half marathon and 21 km Climbathon in Malaysia, becoming the 8th Tower Runner in 2023, despite facing competition from Malaysian and Kenyan runners.

title: Nepal defeated West Indies A in the final match of the T20 series.
content: Nepal won the T20 series final against West Indies 'A' by six wickets. Despite losing the first three matches, Nepal won the fourth and final match in 18.5 overs. Kushal Malla, Asif Sheikh, and Anil Shah scored key runs for Nepal. Obed McCoy took three wickets for West Indies 'A'.
summary: Nepal defeated West Indies 'A' by six wickets in the final match of T20- Series after losing the first three matches consecutively.

title: President sends good wishes to cricket players.
content:
President Paudel wishes good luck to Nepali cricket team for ICC T20 World Cup.

The team leaves for the US tonight to participate in the tournament starting on June 1st.

Nepal is in Group D with South Africa, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, and the Netherlands.

Their first match is against the Netherlands on June 4th.
summary: President Paudel extends well wishes to Nepali cricket team participating in the ICC T20 World Cup Championship, with Nepal facing off against the Netherlands in their first match on June 4th.

title: West Indies wins the Twenty20 series against Team A.
content: West Indies 'A' won the T20 series against Nepal 3-1, with one match remaining. They scored 209 runs and bowled out Nepal for 181. Andre Fletcher (84 runs) top-scored for West Indies 'A', while Rohit Kumar Paudel (82 runs) top-scored for Nepal. Hayden Walsh took three wickets for West Indies 'A', and the fifth and final game will be played on Saturday.
summary: West Indies 'A' clinched the T20 series title with a 28-run win against Nepal in the fourth match, leading the five-match series 3-1.

title: Nepal lost their third match of the T20 series against West Indies by 76 runs.
content: Nepal lost to West Indies 'A' in the third T20 match by 76 runs. Nepal scored 151 runs, while West Indies had scored 227 runs. Karan KC and Sagar Dhakal each took one wicket for Nepal. Nepal has won two matches and lost one in the five-match series so far.
summary: Nepal lost to West Indies 'A' by 76 runs in T20 series, with Johnson Charles scoring a century for West Indies.

title: Nepalese team heads to Asian U-20 Athletics Championship.
content:
Nepali athletes are going to Dubai for Asian U-20 Athletics Championships.

Athletes:
- Badal Karki: 800 and 1500 meter run (men)
- Adeshkumar Yadav: 100 and 200 meter run (men)
- Ajay B.K: 1500 and 3000 meter run (men)
- Kalpana Budha: 1500 and 3000 meter run (women)

Coach: Kanti Mahato
summary: National Sports Council officials bid farewell to the Nepali team participating in the Asian U-20 Athletics Championships in Dubai, with players and a coach representing various running events.

title: Over 11,000 dengue cases in Bagmati, Nepal.
content:
Over 11,000 people in Bagmati Province have gotten dengue fever since July 2023.

Dhading has the most cases (3,501), while Rasuwa has the least (2).

One person in Makwanpur has died from dengue fever this year.

Cases are more common in summer, so the health department is urging people to take precautions and is planning to start a campaign to kill mosquito larvae.
summary: Bagmati Province recorded a severe outbreak of dengue fever, with over 11,409 positive cases since July 2023, with Dhading reporting the highest cases and Rasuwa the lowest.

title: Nepal's approach to population and development focuses on human rights. Deputy Prime Minister Yadav believes that people should be able to make choices about their lives, including having children. He says that Nepal is committed to providing reproductive health services to all citizens.
content:
**Nepal's Approach to Population and Development**

* Nepal believes everyone has rights in matters of population and development.
* It follows this "rights-based approach" to ensure all citizens have a good quality of life.
* Nepal supports the International Conference on Population and Development (ICPD) plan, which aims to achieve sustainable development goals.
* Despite progress since the ICPD, there are still inequalities and challenges that need to be addressed.
* Nepal remains committed to promoting people's rights, gender equality, and sexual and reproductive health.
summary: Nepal emphasizes a rights-based approach to population and development, highlighting progress but acknowledges remaining gaps and challenges in achieving the ICPD Programme of Action.

title: Japan donates disaster prevention community center to developing country.
content: Japan built a community center in Sindhupalchowk to help the community prepare for disasters. The center will have committees, activities, and a warehouse for supplies. It will also have landslide prevention measures. Ambassador Kikuta hopes the center will improve disaster prevention and revitalize the area.
summary: Japan's government handed over a new Community Center for Disaster Prevention to Indrawati Rural Municipality in Sindhupalchowk, enhancing disaster preparedness through a project implemented by JAFS.

title: Dr. Sharma, a parliamentarian, donated Rs. 2 million to a children's hospital to support their medical care.
content: A member of parliament and entrepreneur, Dr. Sunil Sharma, donated two million rupees to a children's hospital being built by Dr. Bhagwan Koirala. The hospital aims to construct specialized children's hospitals in all seven provinces in Nepal, with a 100-bed hospital planned in Kathmandu.
summary: Dr Sunil Sharma donated two million rupees to a children's hospital project initiated by Dr Bhagwan Koirala, which aims to build specialized children's hospitals in all seven provinces of Nepal.

title: Dr. Sharma, a parliamentarian, donated RS 2 million to the Children's Hospital to help the hospital with its operations.
content:
- Dr. Sharma donated 2 million rupees to help build a Children's Hospital.
- The hospital is being built by Dr. Koirala, a surgeon.
- The hospital will have 100 beds in Kathmandu and 50 beds in each of the other 7 provinces.
summary: Dr Sunil Sharma, a member of the House of Representatives, provided two million rupees to the Kathmandu Institute of Child Health, an under-construction children's hospital initiated by Dr Bhagwan Koirala.

title: Children are given vitamin A capsules and deworming tablets to improve their health.
content:
The Department of Health Services has started a free 2-day program to give:

* Vitamin 'A' capsules to children aged 6 months to 5 years.
* De-worming tablets to children aged 1 to 5 years.

The target is to reach 3.2 million children for Vitamin 'A' and 2.9 million for de-worming. Health volunteers and workers will distribute these in every ward. The program happens twice a year, in Baishakh and Kartik.

content:
**Dalit Teen's Death**

In 2016, Ajit Mijar, a Dalit (lower caste) teen, was found dead in suspicious circumstances. His family suspected murder related to his relationship with an "upper caste" girl.

**Court Case and Appeal**

The police initially declared it a suicide, but his father filed a case claiming murder. In 2018, the district court acquitted the accused. The decision was upheld by the high court in 2022.

**Justice Denied**

Despite the suspicions, the accused were acquitted due to lack of evidence. Ajit's family refused to perform his funeral until justice is served.

**Caste Discrimination in Nepal**

The case highlights the systemic caste discrimination in Nepal, where Dalits face barriers in accessing justice. Amnesty International reports that:

* Less than 5% of caste discrimination cases reach the police.
* Dalits are discouraged from filing complaints and may face violence from the police.
* Laws against caste discrimination are not fully implemented, and the statute of limitations is too short.

Amnesty International calls on Nepal to:

* Strengthen the justice system for Dalits
* Improve data collection on caste discrimination
* Provide reparations for victims
summary: On July 14, 2016, 18-year-old Dalit Ajit Mijar was found dead in suspicious circumstances; his family alleges murder but the courts acquitted the accused, highlighting systemic caste-based discrimination and impunity in accessing justice for Dalits in Nepal.

summary: The Janata Samajbadi Party Nepal's split threatens the Madhesh provincial government, with the CPN (Maoist Centre) considering a new government formation, despite the party split having minimal impact on the provincial JSP-Nepal's standing.

title: Yadav plans to challenge new party registration in court.
content:
- Janata Samajbadi Party Nepal (JSP-N) will challenge a decision in court that recognized a splinter group as a new party.
- JSP-N believes the registration of the new party by the Election Commission is illegal, as there are no legal provisions for it.
- The split occurred due to long-standing discontent within the party, with dissident leaders claiming autocratic leadership.
- JSP-N insists it remains the majority party with support from party structures and committees.
- Prime Minister Dahal has received assurances from JSP-N that it will continue to support the ruling alliance.
- JSP-N denies rumors of attempts to form a new government with other parties.
summary: Janata Samajbadi Party Nepal, led by Upendra Yadav, will challenge Election Commission's recognition of a splinter group as a new political party, alleging illegal registration and demanding parliamentary support.

title: Political parties often change their positions on issues to win elections or gain favor with certain groups.
content:
**Summary:**

Last year, the UML demanded a special group of judges to investigate gold smuggling. The Nepali Congress refused.

Now, the UML is in charge and is refusing a similar request from the Congress to investigate Deputy Prime Minister Lamichhane over cooperative fund misuse.

The Congress had supported the UML's request last year, but now opposes their own request.

The UML says their request last year was different because they suspected high-level involvement, so they wanted an independent investigation.

The Congress says they need a committee because they believe the police and other officials are protecting Lamichhane.

The situation highlights how political parties in Nepal change their views based on whether they are in power or not.

Experts say this is not ideal and that parties should trust the state authorities to investigate wrongdoing.
summary: The Nepali Congress and CPN-UML have reversed their demands for probe committees on gold smuggling and cooperative funds misappropriation, highlighting party bias based on governing status.

title: Nepali Congress Party may allow Rabi Lamichhane to speak in Parliament, despite his citizenship issue.
content:
Nepali Congress, the main opposition party, insists on investigating the involvement of Deputy Prime Minister Rabi Lamichhane in a cooperative funds scandal. Lamichhane is accused of embezzling funds, which he denies.

The Congress claims Lamichhane misused the police and Attorney General's Office to clear his name. They believe a parliamentary committee should investigate the matter further.

The ruling parties, including some who initially supported an investigation, now want a broader committee to look into cooperative issues. However, the Congress and others reject this proposal.

The Congress is adamant about blocking House proceedings until the parliamentary committee is formed. They also accuse Lamichhane of trying to tamper with evidence against him.

The meeting also discussed the political situation in Koshi and Gandaki provinces, expressing concerns over the ruling parties' actions in forming governments there.
summary: Nepali Congress demands parliamentary investigation into Deputy Prime Minister Rabi Lamichhane's alleged involvement in cooperative funds embezzlement, while rejecting suggestions for a broader inquiry into the cooperative sector.

title: Three people were arrested for allegedly cheating US applicants by offering fake or altered documents, such as transcripts and recommendation letters.
content: Nepal Police has busted a gang allegedly involved in swindling youths of Rs55 million promising to send them to the United States and Canada through illegal routes.Kathmandu Valley Crime Investigation Office made them public amidst a press conference in Kathmandu on Friday.The arrestees have been identified as Tashi Sherpa, 47, Dimbuti Sherpa, 42, and Nima Sherpa, 19, of Sindhupalchok, according to Senior Superintendent of Police Sanuram Bhattarai.According to him, they allegedly duped ten people of Rs55 million.Meanwhile, a total of 15 Nepalis have been held hostage in different countries including Kenya on their way to the US and it has come to light that the gang took around Rs75 million from them as well.
summary: Nepal Police arrested a gang accused of swindling 10 youths of Rs55 million under the pretext of illegally sending them to the US and Canada; 15 other Nepalis were held hostage in different countries during their journey to the US, with the gang reportedly taking Rs75 million from them.

title: Fire in Bhaktapur injures two people.
content: Two people got hurt in a fire that happened at a carpet factory in Bhaktapur, Nepal. One person has serious burns and is at a special hospital. It took five hours to put out the fire. The factory has a lot of damage, but the police don't know what started the fire yet.

A man named Shankar Pahari died from burns he received while fighting a fire in a community forest in Nepal. Another man, Ramesh Pahari, is still being treated in the hospital.

summary: Death of a firefighter, continued efforts to extinguish a forest fire, and relocation of hospital patients due to encroaching flames.

title: Seven wards in Kolkata Municipal Corporation (KMC) have started segregating waste, with four more set to join soon.
content:
**Kathmandu Waste Segregation**

Seven wards in Kathmandu have started separating trash into two types:

* **Degradable:** Food scraps, plants
* **Non-degradable:** Plastic, metal

Degradable waste is turned into compost for plants in the city. Non-degradable waste is collected separately and may be recycled or sold.

The city plans to expand waste segregation to all 32 wards. This will help reduce the amount of trash in the city.
summary: Kathmandu Metropolitan City implements waste segregation in seven wards, including composting and biogas generation to reduce waste and provide reusable materials.

title: Businesses ask government to spend heavily on infrastructure to boost the economy.
content:
**Nepal's Private Sector Requests Government Support for Economic Growth**

The private sector in Nepal is asking the government to spend more money on infrastructure in the upcoming budget to boost economic growth.

**Reasons for Slow Economic Growth**

* Private investment has been low due to lack of confidence.
* Public spending has also been low.
* The economy has slowed down in sectors like retail and construction.

**Private Sector Requests**

* Encourage investment with an "investment decade" program.
* Provide special incentives for businesses creating jobs.
* Prioritize startups, exports, and tourism.
* Allow companies to reinvest profits.
* Invest social security funds in infrastructure.

**Banking Sector Concerns**

* Banks are facing difficulties lending due to low demand for loans.
* Non-performing loans are increasing, particularly in the construction sector.

**Government Response**

The government plans to:

* Increase private sector confidence through policy reforms.
* Create an investment-friendly environment.
* Spend more money to boost growth.
summary: Nepal's private sector seeks increased government capital expenditure in the upcoming budget to stimulate economic growth amidst a slowdown.

title: Volunteers and locals teamed up to clean up the Barahi Jungle Lodge for a cleaner and healthier environment.
content:
**Barahi Jungle Lodge:**

* Completed a major cleanup near Chitwan National Park, removing tons of waste.
* Conducts regular cleanups as part of its commitment to protecting the environment and promoting sustainability.
* Certified as an eco-friendly establishment under the "Toft Tiger" program and recognized for its environmental management systems (ISO-14001).
summary: Barahi Jungle Lodge concluded an extensive cleanup around Chitwan National Park, removing waste and reaffirming its commitment to eco-friendly practices, earning certifications for its environmental efforts.

title: A new tunnel called Sunkoshi-Marin will provide water to dry farmlands in the Madhesh region of Nepal. This tunnel will bring water from the Sunkoshi River to the Marin River, which will be used to irrigate crops and improve the lives of farmers in the region.
content:
**Sunkoshi Marin Multipurpose Project**

* A 13.3 km tunnel to divert water from the Sunkoshi River to irrigate 122,000 hectares of farmland in central Tarai.
* The Rs 10.05 billion tunnel is complete, six months ahead of schedule.
* Water will be diverted to the Marin River and then to the Bagmati River for irrigation.
* The project includes a 31.07 megawatt hydropower plant and a barrage across the Sunkoshi River.
* It aims to solve water scarcity and boost agricultural production in five drought-prone districts.
* The project will provide year-round irrigation, helping farmers increase crop yields and reduce reliance on imports.
* It will also generate electricity and create economic opportunities.
summary: The breakthrough of the Rs10.05 billion Sunkoshi Marin multipurpose project's diversion tunnel, six months ahead of schedule, will bring year-round irrigation to 122,000 hectares of farmland in five central Tarai districts and generate 31.07 megawatts of electricity.

title: Japanese food festival from May 10th to May 17th
content: Izakaya Hokkaido, a Japanese restaurant in Nepal, will host a three-day Japanese food event from May 10 at Radisson Hotel Kathmandu starting 6:30 pm. The event aims to introduce authentic Japanese cuisine and foster cultural understanding between Japan and Nepal.
summary: Izakaya Hokkaido, a Japanese restaurant in Nepal, is hosting a three-day Japanese food event at the Radisson Hotel Kathmandu starting May 10th to promote cultural understanding and culinary exploration.

title: Pregnant women will be screened for mental health issues as part of a government plan.
content:
**Ministry of Health to Screen Pregnant Women for Mental Health**

To reduce maternal deaths, the Ministry of Health plans to screen pregnant women for mental health issues, which have become a leading cause of deaths.

The screening program will start at a pilot hospital in Kathmandu and will be expanded to other districts in the future.

The program aims to identify and treat mental health problems early on, as suicide and other mental health issues have been linked to maternal deaths in Nepal.

The Ministry is also working on improving the quality of healthcare services and making it easier for women to access care during pregnancy and childbirth.
summary: To reduce Nepal's rising maternal deaths, the Ministry of Health plans to screen pregnant women for mental health problems, starting at a pilot hospital and gradually expanding to other districts.

title: Medics get trained to screen for noncommunicable diseases.
content: Health workers in Kathmandu have been trained to screen patients for non-communicable diseases (NCDs) like high blood pressure, heart disease, and diabetes. These workers will provide free screening and medicines for some NCDs. NCDs are now a major cause of death in Nepal, so early screening is important to reduce the burden.
summary: 50 health workers in Kathmandu were trained to screen patients for non-communicable diseases like high blood pressure, heart disease, and cancer, which account for 71% of deaths in Nepal, with medicines for some being provided free of cost.

title: Only 2% of new drugs in the market are tested within nine months.
content: The Department of Drug Administration has tested less than 2% of registered medicines in Nepal, leaving many substandard drugs undetected. The department has tested 348 samples in nine months, but some samples collected 13 months ago still need to be tested. The laboratory has found some medicines to be substandard, leading to recalls, but testing capacity is limited. Despite the sale of thousands of medicines, DDA inspectors only collect around 1,000 samples annually due to understaffing. The drug inspectors' task is difficult as they must monitor over 21,000 registered pharmacies and many unregistered ones.
summary: In nine months, Nepal's Drug Administration tested less than 2% of registered medicines, despite collecting hundreds of suspected substandard drug samples.

title: Dirty air causes asthma in young children.
content:
**Air pollution in Kathmandu is causing health problems in children, including asthma.**

* Outdoor and indoor air pollution exposes children to health hazards such as asthma, lung problems, skin disease, and pregnancy loss.
* Experts say air quality affects public health, causing short-term issues like pneumonia and long-term issues like cancer and heart disease.
* Children are particularly vulnerable to asthma from air pollution, and cases have increased.
* If a child has shortness of breath, trouble sleeping, or wheezing, it's important to seek medical help for possible asthma.
* Other factors like allergies and family history can also contribute to childhood asthma.
* Air pollution has shortened the lives of Nepali people by an average of five years, with some areas losing up to 7.5 years of life expectancy due to toxic air.
summary: Air pollution linked to increased childhood asthma, causing a significant impact on the health of children in Nepal, with studies indicating a reduction in life expectancy due to exposure to toxic air.

title: Residents in seven districts to receive medicine to prevent elephantiasis.
content:
**Mass Drug Administration to Fight Elephantiasis in Nepal**

- Preparations are ready to administer anti-elephantiasis medicines in seven districts.
- Everyone over two years old in these areas will get the medicine for two weeks.
- Health workers will visit homes to make sure everyone receives the medication.
- This could be the last year of this campaign as the government's budget is limited.
- Nepal aims to eliminate elephantiasis by 2030.
- So far, the disease has been eliminated from 70 out of 77 districts.
summary: Nepal's Epidemiology and Disease Control Division is conducting a two-week mass drug administration campaign against elephantiasis in seven endemic districts, targeting everyone over two years old with anti-parasitic drugs as part of a bid to eliminate the disease by 2030 despite budget constraints.

title: Nepalese cuisine is now available in New York, expanding the city's culinary offerings.
content:
**Aditya Mishra: Nepali Chef Elevating Cuisine in New York**

Aditya Mishra, a Nepali chef, aims to promote Nepali food globally. After studying engineering, he moved to New York to pursue his passion for cooking.

Mishra worked in Michelin-starred restaurants and won scholarships. He founded "The Sewing Tin," a supper club serving Nepali and Indian cuisines.

Through his dishes, Mishra shares stories of Nepali culture. He believes in blending traditional and modern culinary styles.

Despite challenges as an outsider in New York, Mishra focuses on sharing his culture and passion. He encourages chefs to innovate and create meaningful food experiences.

Mishra's signature dish, Confit Duck Chatamari, combines Nepali chatamari with French confit duck, creating a unique and flavorful dish.
summary: Nepali chef Aditya Mishra, recipient of the James Beard Foundation scholarship, promotes Nepali cuisine globally through his supper club "The Sewing Tin," serving innovative dishes like "Confit Duck Chatamari" that blend Nepali flavors with French techniques.

title:

- Versatile food that can be cooked in many ways

content:
**Potatoes in Nepal**

- Potatoes are a staple food in Nepal, especially in mountainous areas.
- They are versatile and affordable, used in many dishes.
- Potatoes are rich in nutrients like vitamins C and B6, potassium, and fiber.
- They can help lower blood pressure, reduce cholesterol, and boost digestive health.
- Nepal grows a lot of potatoes, but also imports some.
- There are different types of potatoes, including red, white, and blue.
- While potatoes are healthy, consuming a lot of chips and fries can lead to weight gain and nutrient loss.
- Diabetics should limit their potato intake to avoid blood sugar spikes.
summary: Potatoes, a staple food in Nepal, provide essential nutrients, are versatile in cuisine, and benefit health in various ways.

title:
**Eggs: A Nutritional Powerhouse**

* Eggs are a highly nutritious food, packed with protein, healthy fats, vitamins, and minerals.
* One large egg contains about 6 grams of protein, which is essential for building and repairing body tissues.
* Eggs are a good source of lutein and zeaxanthin, antioxidants that protect eye health.
* They also contain choline, a nutrient important for brain function and memory.
* Eggs are a versatile food that can be enjoyed in many ways, such as boiled, fried, or scrambled.
* Consuming eggs in moderation can be part of a healthy diet.
content: Chicken eggs are healthy and nutritious, containing many vitamins and minerals. They are a complete source of protein and have been linked to a reduction in malnutrition and other health benefits. Nepal produces enough eggs to meet its domestic demand. Most eggs are available in two sizes: big and medium. Pastured eggs from local chickens are more nutritious but more expensive. It's recommended to eat 1-2 eggs per day for a healthy adult. There is no mechanism in Nepal to check the quality of eggs. Eggs offer various benefits, including weight loss, reduced blood pressure, protection against infections, and benefits for skin, bones, and mental energy.
summary: Chicken eggs provide a complete source of protein, minerals, and vitamins, offering numerous health benefits including weight loss, reduced blood pressure, infection protection, prenatal bone strengthening, cognitive enhancement, and skin health.

title:
**7 Must-Visit Places in Nepal for 2024:**

- Kathmandu: Bustling capital with ancient temples, vibrant markets, and stunning views.
- Pokhara: Serene lakeside town with breathtaking mountain panoramas and adventure activities.
- Chitwan National Park: UNESCO World Heritage site with a diverse wildlife, including rhinos and tigers.
- Everest Base Camp Trek: Epic hike to the base of Mount Everest, offering unforgettable views.
- Annapurna Circuit Trek: Challenging but rewarding trek through stunning Himalayan landscapes.
- Lumbini: Birthplace of Lord Buddha, a sacred pilgrimage site with peaceful monasteries.
- Bardia National Park: Another UNESCO World Heritage site with abundant wildlife and diverse ecosystems.
content:
**Mundhum Trek:**

* New cultural trail in eastern Nepal through indigenous villages and landscapes.
* Panoramic views of famous mountains including Everest.
* Advised to carry tents for accommodation.

**Janaki Mandir:**

* Largest temple in Nepal, built in 1874.
* Houses an idol of Sita, Lord Ram's wife.
* Vivaha Panchami celebration commemorates Ram and Sita's marriage.

**Kuri Village:**

* Popular tourist destination at high altitude (3,842 m).
* Enjoy snow, landscapes, and mountain views during winter.
* Chains used on vehicles for access during snowfall.

**Annapurna Base Camp:**

* Picturesque trek to the foothills of Annapurna South (4,130 m).
* Rich cultural diversity and beautiful Nepali villages.
* Affordable and year-round trek, but autumn and spring are best.

**Bardiya National Park:**

* Home to Royal Bengal Tigers.
* Also has Asian elephants and greater one-horned rhinoceros.
* Best time to visit: March-May and September-December.

**Khaptad National Park:**

* Pristine protected area with varied landscapes.
* Trekkers should bring their tents and supplies.
* Spring and autumn offer ideal trekking weather.
summary: Mundhum Trek through indigenous villages leads to Silchung Peak, Janaki Mandir pilgrimage site for Sita's idol, Kuri Village with scenic views and snow, Annapurna Base Camp trek to Annapurna South, Bardiya National Park for Royal Bengal Tigers, Khaptad National Park in the far west for scenic hikes, and Limi Valley in Humla for cultural experiences.

title:
* Phidim, a town in Nepal, holds many memories for the narrator.
* The narrator returns to Phidim after some years and finds that while some things have changed, others remain the same.
* Despite the changes, the narrator still feels a deep connection to the town and its people.
content:
**Hometown Revisited**

After a long journey, the author returned to his hometown, Phidim. He found that it had changed significantly: old houses replaced by concrete buildings, roads paved, and new buildings constructed. Despite the changes, he still recognized his childhood home and explored the nooks and crannies, reminiscing about the memories he had there.

The author also visited the school where he spent his teenage years, and the Shivalaya temple, a place he used to hang out with friends. He learned that the lack of quality education and healthcare had driven many people away from Phidim.

Despite the changes, the author still feels a deep connection to his hometown. He realizes that Phidim is evolving, trading its rural charm for urbanization. People are moving to the town for better opportunities, but many are also leaving for greener pastures.

As the author leaves Phidim, he reflects on the inevitability of leaving a place, no matter how much he loves it. He bids farewell to the Kanchhi Dokan and points out Kanchenjunga and Kumbhakarna to his daughter, symbols of his childhood. Phidim, now a blend of nostalgia and change, remains etched in his heart.
summary: After a treacherous journey through Pauwa Bhanjyang and Kanchhi Dokan, the author returned to his hometown Phidim, which has undergone significant transformation over the years, with mud and stone houses replaced by concrete buildings, leaving him nostalgic for the past but also recognizing its evolution into a transit town for pilgrims and a destination for those seeking better opportunities.

title: Architecture and art merge to create unique and captivating spaces.
content:
**Bara Imambara: A Historical Gem in Lucknow**

Lucknow welcomes visitors with a smile. The city is known for its rich history and delicious food.

Bara Imambara, built in 1784, is a grand complex with a huge hall (Asafi Hall) that has no pillars or beams supporting its massive arched roof. The hall houses the tomb of Asaf-ud-Daula, the Nawab of Lucknow.

The complex also features:

* Asafi Mosque with its beautiful calligraphy and designs
* Bhool Bhulaiyaa (labyrinth) with confusing corridors and staircases
* Shahi Baoli (royal stepwell) with natural temperature regulation and a well that reflects visitors like a CCTV camera
summary: Bara Imambara, built as a famine relief project in 1784, features the Rumi Darwaza, Asafi Mosque, Asafi Hall with a pillarless arched roof, the labyrinthine Bhool Bhulaiyaa, a panoramic city view from the roof, and the Shahi Baoli, an underground stepwell with a CCTV-like function.

title: Explore breathtaking landscapes and hidden trails with us. From serene wilderness paths to challenging mountain ascents, we offer a range of treks and trails tailored to all levels of experience. Immerse yourself in nature, savor panoramic views, and forge unforgettable memories.
content:
Climbing mountains like Everest is challenging and requires physical and mental strength.

**Tips for New Trekkers:**

* Stay positive and push through tough times.
* Start training at least a month before your trek with activities like walking and stretching.
* Pack light and warm clothing in your backpack.
* Bring essentials like a down jacket, hat, sunglasses, sunscreen, gloves, and sturdy boots.
* Women should carry period supplies.
* If you experience altitude sickness, rest and take medication.
* Communicate well with your guide and fellow trekkers.

**Challenges for Female Trekkers:**

* They may face underestimation and negative comments about their abilities.
* They need to handle period symptoms while trekking.

**Becoming a Trekking Guide:**

* Connect with a trekking association and take a guide course.
* Courses teach skills like map reading, navigation, and safety measures.
* Colleges also offer bachelor's programs in mountaineering.
summary: Ascending challenging mountains like Everest requires physical and mental endurance, preparation with essential gear, and support from experienced guides who emphasize positivity, communication, and accommodation for potential altitude sickness and periods.

title:
Traveling Nepal Solo

- Don't be afraid to ask for help. The Nepalese people are very friendly and helpful.

title: Nepal won the final match against West Indies A, securing the series victory with a 2-3 score.
content:

Nepal defeated West Indies A by six wickets thanks to excellent batting by Aasif Sheikh, Anil Sah, and Kushal Malla, along with impressive bowling by Sagar Dhakal and Sompal Kami.

Rohit Paudel was named player of the series for his 265 runs.

summary: Nepal defeated West Indies A by six wickets in the fifth T20, with Aasif Sheikh, Anil Sah, and Kushal Malla leading the batting, while Sagar Dhakal and Sompal Kami impressed with the ball, despite West Indies A winning the series 3-2.

title: unauthorised-translation-and-piracy-of-foreign-books-thrive-in-nepal
content:
**Unauthorized Book Translations Flourish in Nepal**

Nepali publishers widely translate books without permission from authors or publishers. These unauthorized translations are often poorly done, hurting both authors and readers.

**Notable Examples:**

* Taslima Nasrin's books have been pirated and translated without her approval.
* The Nepali translations of "Steve Jobs" and "Rich Dad Poor Dad" lack official deals.

**Consequences:**

* Poor quality translations harm the reputation of Nepal's book industry.
* Authors lose royalties and revenue.
* Readers are misled by inaccurate and incomplete translations.

**Legal Framework:**

* Nepal's Copyright Act prohibits unauthorized translations.
* The law has not been effectively enforced.

**Causes:**

* Small market size reduces incentive for publishers to seek permission.
* Lack of regulatory mechanisms and quality control.
* Increased import taxes on books.

**Solutions:**

* Publishers should engage in authorized translations.
* Government should strengthen copyright enforcement.
* Establish a regulatory body to monitor translation quality.
summary: Nepali book market is rampant with unauthorized translations of popular international works, including those by Taslima Nasrin, Steve Jobs, and Robert Kiyosaki, despite copyright laws and the availability of authorized translations.

title: Young people from a region where Communist rebels are active in India are migrating to the United States in search of better opportunities.
content:
**Youth in Nepal Trek Through 'Backdoor' to US, Losing Millions**

Many youths from a rural Nepalese village have illegally traveled to the United States, costing them millions of rupees in loans and fees.

**Costs and Risks:**

* Eight youths deported, losing an average of Rs. 6 million each.
* Loans taken at high interest rates (up to 36%).
* Families burdened with debt and creditors' pressure.
* Five families have fled the village due to debt.

**Journey to the US:**

* Traveled through multiple countries, facing harsh conditions.
* Detained in the US, held in camps for months or years.
* Refugee applications often rejected, leading to deportation.

**Mental Health Impact:**

* Deported youths experience anxiety and depression.
* Struggle to find employment in Nepal, making it difficult to repay debts.

**Underlying Causes:**

* Lack of economic opportunities in impoverished areas.
* Organized human traffickers take advantage of vulnerable youth.
* Creditors encourage illegal travel.

**Government Response:**

* Local governments and political parties show little concern.
* Police receive few complaints due to fear of retaliation.
* Anti-Human Trafficking Bureau lacks specific laws to address this issue.
* Human trafficking thrives in areas where the Maoist insurgency weakened the traditional economy and displaced people.
summary: Bharat Budha, chair of Putha Uttarganga Rural Municipality‚Äôs ward 10, knows that many youths from his village have made it to the United States via ‚Äòtallo bato‚Äô‚Äîbackdoor route‚Äîand that many are still on the way. He also knows that eight of them have been deported from the country and that they have lost a cumulative Rs45 million in the process. The deported youths say that they returned home empty-handed after facing unspeakable ordeals and lost Rs6 million each on average.The Tak village in Rukum East‚Äîa close-knit settlement of 425 houses‚Äîwas considered the Maoists‚Äô ‚Äòbase area‚Äô during the insurgency. Village youths who reached the US through illegal routes and got deported have lost an estimated Rs40 million. The number of those who returned without completing the journey and the amount they lost remain unknown.To get to the US, the youths have taken loans at up to 36 percent interest per annum from their relatives and village landowners. In Tak village, at least one person each from half of the households has gone abroad, Budha said. ‚ÄúYouths started going to America about six-seven years ago,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIf they could gather enough money, the whole village would try to go to the US.‚Äù Budha‚Äôs own son had reached the US illegally in 2017, spending Rs3.2 million.During the insurgency, outsize slogans of revolution would adorn the walls of houses in the village. Hoping for a better life, people from all walks of life helped out the Maoists. But now, village youths are paying the agents to illegally get to the US‚Äîa country that the Maoists used to call their ‚Äòenemy‚Äô, an ‚Äòimperialistic force‚Äô. This has cost the Tak village much and in multiple ways.Death of a dreamSome of the deported youths have chosen to flee the village altogether, burdened with debt and creditors‚Äô pressure. At least five such families have already left, said a resident. The family of Ram Budha was one of them. On April 28, 2015, Ram, who had returned to Nepal after working in Malaysia for eight years, took the illegal route to the US. He travelled through arduous trails for months and finally arrived in the country. Upon reaching the country, he was detained and had to stay at the detention camp for 27 months. When his refugee application was rejected, he was deported to Nepal in mid-December 2019. He lost Rs4.5 million in the process. He now owes over Rs6 million to creditors. ‚ÄúAfter the creditors began to put pressure on me, I couldn‚Äôt live in the village peacefully,‚Äù said Ram, who currently runs a vegetable farm in Tarakeshwar, Kathmandu.While those who got to the US through illegal routes and fortunately got refugee status there narrate their stories with pride, those who have been deported or returned from half-way have tragic tales to tell.Nanda Kala Gharti, who lives in a small stone house on the upper flank of Tak village, spends her days in melancholy. Her husband, Dhanlal, had chosen to take the illegal route to the US, and Nanda Kala, a mother of four, is living with the repercussions of his decision. Dhanlal had got into the US after a six-month long arduous journey and was detained immediately. He had to spend four years in the detention camp, before he was deported to Nepal. He had already lost Rs6 million.Nanda Kala said they now have an insurmountable crisis in their hands. Pointing to her son, she exclaimed, ‚ÄúWhen will he grow up, go abroad and pay back the loans!‚ÄùDhanlal himself tried to go to Croatia once and spent 15 days in Kathmandu for the process. But after he was turned down, he returned home dejected. ‚ÄúNow we will submit the passport to another agent [for Dhanlal‚Äôs trip abroad],‚Äù Nanda Kala said. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no point staying here.‚ÄùStories that echo each otherThe situation in Sisne Rural Municipality is similar to that of Putha Uttarganga. Here, one can hear plenty of stories of those who have tried to go to the US and those who are fighting refugee cases there. Krishna Regmi, chair of the rural municipality, personally knows seven people who have been deported from the US.Gangaram Khadka, a resident of Sisne-3, runs a bee and chicken farm. Like other young men in his village, Khadka had headed off to the US via an illegal route on 27 March, 2018. He had reached the US via the New Delhi-Moscow-Barcelona-Bogota-Panama-Costa Rica-Nicaragua-Honduras-Guatemala-Mexico route. When he finally arrived in the US, he was detained and had to spend 11 months in detention. He was deported on 15 March, 2019. He had handed over Rs3.2 millions to the agent and spent Rs2 million to fight the case to become a refugee. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not possible for me to pay back the loan while working in Nepal,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI aim to pay back some interest and head off abroad again.‚ÄùFor six months after Khadka was deported, he had anxiety and headache, he said, adding the three people from his village who were deported like him are also struggling with their mental health.Tikaram Pun, a 40-year-old resident of Bohora village in Musikot-4, is also haunted by his past journey. In September 2017, he reached the US after crossing 17 countries with the help of organised human traffickers. Of the 41 people in his group, 31 were from Rukum East and Rukum West, he said. Pun, who was detained on arrival in the US, spent 24 months in a detention camp. His refugee application was also refused and so he was deported along with eight other Nepalis. ‚ÄúWhen I returned, I started having mental health problems. I still suffer from them,‚Äù he said. Pun is under pressure from creditors and relatives to pay back the Rs9.2 million loan he had taken for the task.Those who died on the wayA group of 10 Bangladeshis and seven Nepalis, including Rupak Bohora of Bafikot-3 in Rukum West, were on a mission to reach Costa Rica through Colombia, Caribbean Coast, Capuragana and Panama. But while they were crossing a sea, their boat capsized. As many as 12 died in the incident, including six Nepalis. Rupak‚Äôs wife, Geeta, learned about the incident only after six days, on 25 June, 2021.‚ÄúI still don‚Äôt know what exactly happened,‚Äù said Geeta, who had been married off at age 19 and is now a mother of two daughters. The only thing she knows is that Rupak has died and she is now all alone. And that she has Rs5 million in loan taken for Rupak‚Äôs trip. She showed a picture of her husband on her phone to this scribe and said, ‚ÄúI only have memories.‚ÄùLack of political will and legal remediesThe concrete bridge over Chewang river is on the edge of Tak village. On the walls of the bridge are paintings of political theorists like Marx, Engels, Lenin, Stalin and Mao, and the iconic slogan, ‚ÄòWorkers of the world, unite!‚Äô, below them. But the slogan appears to be at odds with life in the village. Given the phenomenon of illegal travels to the US through the help of organised human traffickers, the whole village appears to be emptying. Neither the local governments are concerned about the phenomenon nor are the political parties paying attention.Puniraj Gharti, chair of Putha Uttarganga Rural Municipality, said though the trend is worrying, there‚Äôs nothing he can do. ‚ÄúHow could we stop them from making the trip when they are struggling to make a living in the village?‚Äù he said.Krishna Regmi, chair of Sisne Rural Municipality, said that the vicious cycle of poverty started after marijuana farming was banned in the country. Then the Maoist insurgency added to the woe, forcing youths to migrate. The signing of the peace agreement in 2006 didn‚Äôt herald any change in the economy either and youths are struggling to get jobs. Organised human traffickers are cashing in on this sorry state of affairs, Regmi said. ‚ÄúMeter byajis [usurious lenders] are also promoting this phenomenon,‚Äù he added.The phenomenon is equally rife in Dang‚Äôs Tulsipur and Ghorahi. Ramesh Kumar Pandey, chair of Ghorai-15, says that even though many heading to the US are swindled, no complaints are filed at the ward office. ‚ÄúOnly those who attempt to go to Saudi Arabia or Qatar file the complaints,‚Äù he said.One can infer from Pandey‚Äôs statements that the families of such illegal travellers don‚Äôt want to publicise the ordeals of their family members. On the one hand, agents threaten them to not publicise the issue; on the other, they fear they themselves would be punished by law.According to the Anti-Human Trafficking Bureau, as many as 178 Nepalis, including 174 men, have been deported from the US in the five fiscal years after 2018-19. Of them, the highest 49 are from Rukum while 37 are from Dang. The data doesn‚Äôt include those who returned after making it to the half-way or those who have been fighting the legal battle in the US for refugee status. But this data is enough to show that many such youths are from the ‚Äòbase areas‚Äô of the Maoist insurgency.SSP Jeevan Shrestha, chief of the bureau, said that data on the number of such victims and the amounts they have spent is hard to collect since complaints are rarely filed with the police. ‚ÄúThis is human trafficking but for a lack of law, we are still compelled to launch the cases as per Human Trafficking and Transportation (Control) Act 2074 BS,‚Äù Shrestha said. ‚ÄúThe Act provides a maximum penalty of Rs250,000 for the offenders and 50 percent of that as compensation to the victims.‚Äù Without specific law, police also invoke the theft and organised crime act to punish the offenders, he added.On the one hand, police receive no complaints; on the other, the phenomenon sees no control.Bhaskar Gautam, a political scientist, says the rise in cases of human trafficking in the insurgency‚Äôs ‚Äòbase areas‚Äô is due to the political system‚Äôs abject failure.While the Maoists raised issues related to livelihood, nationalism and a new kind of democracy to fuel their war machine, after the peace process, it is livelihoods that have been hit the hardest, Gautam said. ‚ÄúThe traditional way of life and economy took a hit during the insurgency,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúDevelopments after the peace process also failed to address that. What sprang up was organised human trafficking.‚Äù(Mahesh KC in Rukum East and Durgalal KC in Dang contributed to this report.)This report is prepared in collaboration with the Center for Investigative Journalism-Nepal.

title: Poor patients in India often struggle to get a bed in a private hospital. Even if they can afford it, private hospitals often give priority to patients who can pay more. This leads to poor patients being neglected, and even dying due to lack of timely care.
content:
**Government mandates**

* Private hospitals must provide 10% of beds and free treatment to the poor.

**Patient's experience**

* Gyanumaya BK was unaware of the mandate and spent a lot of money on medical bills.
* Many patients do not know about the mandate and cannot access free services.

**Hospital's response**

* Pokhara's Metrocity Hospital does not follow the mandate and provides discounts instead.
* Some hospitals claim to follow the mandate but have not provided proof.
* Private hospitals in other cities also ignore the mandate.

**Monitoring**

* Regulatory bodies have no data on whether hospitals are following the mandate.
